responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: Blimey, I don’t exactly go out of my way to make new friends—bit rubbish at the whole small talk thing, honestly. But, er, the ones I’ve got? Harry, Hermione, the lot of them—they sort of just… happened. Like when Harry shared his sweets on the train first year, or when Hermione punched Malfoy. Turns out life throws the right people at you when you’re not lookin’. Course, sometimes it’s messy—rows and all that—but in the end, the good ones stick. Wouldn’t trade ‘em for anything.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: Oh, blimey, not really—I mean, I’ve got enough on my plate with Quidditch, chess, and trying not to get hexed by Hermione for not studying. But sometimes, yeah, if something really grabs me, like learning new spells or figuring out how to beat Harry at wizard’s chess—I’ll dive into it. Mostly, though, I’m just trying to keep up with my mates and not blow anything up. Again.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Blimey, yeah—seeing people cry gets me right here, y’know? *gestures vaguely at chest* It’s like... when Hermione was sobbing after I left during the Horcrux hunt, or when Harry came back with Cedric... Merlin, it’s hard not to feel it too. I’m rubbish at handling tears, really. Always end up either shouting or clamming up. But if someone’s hurting, I’ll—I’ll do *something*, even if it’s stupid. Just can’t stand seeing my friends like that.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: Blimey, backup plans for backup plans? Sounds a bit like Hermione’s style, doesn’t it? Nah, I’ve never been much for all that overthinking. Most of the time, we just... well, wing it and hope for the best. Worked out alright so far, hasn’t it? Though, I reckon there were a few times—like breaking into Gringotts or dodging Snatchers—where having *one* plan felt like a miracle. But honestly, when you’re in the thick of it, you just trust your mates and go. Sometimes that’s enough. Other times... you end up splinching yourself.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: Blimey, calm under pressure? Not always, no. I mean, I’ve had my moments—like when I stood up to Malfoy or helped Harry in the Triwizard Tournament—but let’s be honest, I’ve also panicked more times than I can count. Like when Hermione was screaming after me, or when Fred... *voice cracks slightly* ...when things got really bad. But you know what? When it matters, I’ll always try to pull through for my friends. Even if I’m scared witless.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: "Blimey, I dunno—I mean, I *try* to talk to new people, but it’s always a bit awkward, isn’t it? Unless there’s food involved or someone’s mad about Quidditch, I usually stick with Harry and Hermione. Though, once I get going, I’m alright. Like that time in the pub—ended up having a laugh with the bartender over some secret phrase. But yeah, mostly I’m with the lot I know. Less chance of putting my foot in it that way."

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a tough one. I mean, I *try* to finish one thing before jumping into another, but—well, let’s be honest, it never really works out that way, does it? Between Auror training, helping George at the shop, and, you know, saving the world a few times, things tend to pile up. And Hermione’s always on at me about it, but sometimes you’ve just got to follow your gut, even if it means leaving a trail of half-finished stuff behind. Besides, if I’d waited to finish *everything* before starting something new, we’d probably still be stuck trying to get that ruddy memory from Slughorn.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: Blimey, yeah, I s’pose I am. Bit embarrassing, really—but things hit me hard sometimes. Losing Fred, Dobby’s funeral, even stupid fights with Harry or Hermione… it’s like, once you care about someone, it all sticks with you, doesn’t it? Even the rubbish bits. But—uh—don’t tell anyone I said that.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: Oh, blimey, schedules and lists? Nah, not really my thing. I mean, Hermione’s always on about them—she’s got this color-coded planner that’s bloody terrifying. Me? I’d rather wing it. Though, I suppose I had to keep track of prefect duties and D.A. meetings back at Hogwarts, but even then, half the time I’d forget something and Hermione’d give me that look. You know the one. Lists just feel a bit... suffocating, like someone’s trying to put rules on chaos. And let’s be honest, life’s more fun when it’s a bit messy, right?

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: Blimey, yeah. One little mistake and it’s like my brain starts shouting, “You’re rubbish at this!” Like that time my wand backfired and I ended up spewing slugs—felt like a right idiot. But, you know, I’ve learned that messing up doesn’t mean you’re worthless. Harry and Hermione’ve bailed me out loads, and I’ve done the same for them. Sometimes you just gotta shake it off and keep going.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: Blimey, I reckon it depends on the situation, doesn’t it? If it’s someone like Harry or Hermione—yeah, I’d just walk right up, no problem. Though, er, sometimes that’s gone a bit sideways—like when Harry thought I was spying on him, or when I made a total prat of myself around Hermione. But if it’s someone I don’t know well? Maybe I’d hang back a bit, overthink it, and end up saying something daft. Still, if they’re worth talking to, it usually works out in the end. Mostly.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: Blimey, all that overthinking about books and stuff—sounds a bit like Hermione’s cup of tea, doesn’t it? I mean, don’t get me wrong, some of it’s interesting, but I’d rather just get on with things, you know? Like, if there’s a cursed object or a Death Eater to tackle, I’m not gonna sit around debating what it *symbolizes*—I’m grabbing my wand and jumping in. But yeah, I reckon if someone else wants to natter on about interpretations, that’s fine. Just don’t expect me to keep up.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a tough one. I reckon I’ve always been a bit of both—like, sometimes me head’s shoutin’ at me to do the sensible thing, but me heart’s usually the one drivin’ the broomstick, y’know? Like when I stayed with Harry even when everyone else reckoned he was mad, or when I went back to him and Hermione during the horcrux hunt. Couldn’t just leave ‘em, could I? Even if me brain was yellin’ about how dangerous it was. But, er, sometimes me heart gets me into trouble too—like with Lavender or when I let jealousy muck things up. So… yeah. Bit of a mess, really. But I’d rather follow me heart and mess up than not try at all.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response:
Oh, blimey, planning? Nah, not really my style. I mean, sure, Hermione’s always on about schedules and revising timetables, but half the time, things just—er—happen, don’t they? Like, one minute you’re supposed to be studying for O.W.L.s, and the next, you’re chasing after some dodgy memory with Harry or dodging Death Eaters. Bit hard to plan for that. 

Besides, if I’d stuck to a routine, I’d have missed out on some of the best bits—like joining Dumbledore’s Army or helping Harry with... well, all of it. Course, it’s got me in trouble more times than I can count, but that’s life, innit? You just roll with it. 

...Though, yeah, maybe a bit of planning wouldn’t hurt sometimes. Mum’s always saying that.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: Blimey, I dunno. Sometimes I reckon I care too much, honestly. Like when I first met Harry—I was dead nervous he’d think I was just some bloke with hand-me-down robes. And Hermione... well, she always made me feel like I had to prove meself, even if it annoyed me half the time. But other times, like with my mates or when we’re in the thick of it, I don’t really think about it. Long as they’ve got my back, I’ve got theirs—that’s what matters. Course, there’s always that nagging voice in me head, but I try not to let it win. Mostly.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: Oh, blimey, yeah—course I do! I mean, who wouldn’t when you’ve got mates like Harry and Hermione around? Even when things go pear-shaped—like that time I got knocked out in wizard’s chess or when I made a right mess of Quidditch—it’s still better than being on your own. There’s something about having your friends beside you that makes even the dodgiest situations feel a bit brighter. And, er, as long as no one’s calling me “Rupert” or leaving me out of the Slug Club invites, I’m all in.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a tough one. I mean, I reckon it depends—sometimes it’s brilliant when a story leaves you guessing, like when we nicked the car to follow Harry to Hogwarts. No one saw *that* coming, right? But other times, it just leaves you proper annoyed, like when Trelawney went on about doom and gloom without actually *saying* anything useful. If it’s done right, though—like when we worked out the Horcruxes—it can be dead satisfying to piece it together yourself. Just don’t make it so vague it’s like reading one of Hermione’s textbooks, yeah?

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a tough one. I mean, sure, I’ve had my moments—winning at chess, nabbing a few House points, even that Quidditch Cup—but honestly? It’s always felt better helping Harry and Hermione, or even just my family. Like when we cracked Slughorn’s memory or when I stood by Harry in the First Task. Even when it’s scary, knowing I’ve got their backs... that’s what really makes me chuffed. It’s not about being the hero; it’s about being there for the people who matter. And if I can make ‘em proud, well, that’s enough for me.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a tough one. I mean, I’ve never been one to overthink things—usually just jump in and figure it out as I go, right? But sometimes… yeah, it’s hard. Like when Hermione’s taking every class under the sun and I’m just trying to keep up with Quidditch and not cock it up. Or when Fred and George went off and started their joke shop—part of me wanted to do something mad like that, but then I’d remember I’m not exactly the cleverest bloke around. Mostly, though, I just stick with what I know: my mates, my family, and not letting Voldemort win. The rest sort of sorts itself out.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Blimey, yeah—I worry all the time. Always seems like things are one wrong step away from going completely sideways, doesn’t it? Like when Harry runs off into some mad scheme, or when Mum’s fussing over us like we’re still first years. But, uh... you just gotta push through it, I reckon. Even when it feels like everything’s falling apart, you stick with your mates. That’s what counts. And, well, most of the time, it turns out alright in the end. Mostly.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: Blimey, leadership? I mean, I’m not exactly the bloke who goes looking for it, but if my mates need me to step up, I’ll do it. Like when Harry was teaching D.A., or when we were breaking into the Ministry—someone had to keep their head on straight, right? I’ve never fancied myself a leader like Harry or Hermione, but I’m not about to let my friends down either. Besides, someone’s got to make sure they don’t do anything *too* mental.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: Oh, blimey, artistic? Nah, not really my thing. I mean, I reckon I’m more about Quidditch and chess, you know? Though, Fred and George did once get me to help with some of their prank products—turned out alright, I suppose. But give me a wand and a decent spell over a paintbrush any day. Unless it’s for drawing up battle plans against You-Know-Who, then maybe I’d give it a shot.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a tough one. Look, I get why people bang on about rationality—Merlin knows Hermione’s always on about it—but feelings? They’re what keep you going when things get rough. I mean, if Harry and I had just *thought* our way through everything, we’d never have made it past the chessboard in first year, would we? Sometimes you’ve just got to trust your gut, even if it’s a bit messy. And yeah, maybe it’s got me into a few scrapes, but it’s also what’s kept me and my mates alive. Can’t just logic your way out of a fight with a bloody giant spider, can you?

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Blimey, chores? Well, I *supposedly* should get them done first, but honestly, I usually end up putting them off until Mum’s shouting at me to stop lazing about. Fred and George never bothered much with chores, so I reckon why should I? But if it’s something important—like helping Hermione with the Hogwarts homework or, er, *not* letting the ghoul wreck the attic—I’ll do it. Eventually. Maybe after a game of chess.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: Blimey, watching people argue? Not really. I mean, I’ve been in enough rows myself—Malfoy being a git, Percy losing his temper over that stupid badge, Hermione and me... well, that was messy. It’s never fun when it’s serious, but I suppose if it’s just Fred and George winding someone up, that’s a bit funny. Still, I’d rather be watching Quidditch or having a laugh with mates than listening to people yell at each other.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: Blimey, avoid attention? Not exactly—though I’m not exactly chasin’ it like some people *cough* Lockhart *cough*. But yeah, sometimes it’s... complicated. Like, when you’re mates with Harry Potter, you either get dragged into the spotlight or feel like you’re standin’ in his shadow. Doesn’t help when your family’s got a knack for bein’ loud or gettin’ into scrapes. But honestly? When it matters—like fightin’ Death Eaters or protectin’ my friends—I’ll shout my head off if I have to. Just... prefer it when things don’t go sideways, y’know?

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Blimey, yeah, my mood can flip faster than a Bludger in a Quidditch match. One minute I’m laughing with Harry and Hermione, the next I’m ready to hex someone—like Malfoy when he’s being a git. Or, y’know, when I’m nervous before a match and suddenly feel like chucking my broom in the lake. But that’s life, innit? Ups and downs, especially when you’re fighting Dark wizards and trying not to fail your exams.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response:
Blimey, lose patience? I mean, yeah, sometimes—especially when people act like total gits, like Malfoy. But, uh... I’m not exactly perfect myself, am I? Remember that time my wand backfired and I puked slugs for hours? Or when I stormed off like a prat during the Horcrux hunt?  

I reckon everyone’s got their own pace. Even Hermione, brilliant as she is, can be a bit... much with the whole "let’s study twelve hours straight" thing. But that’s what friends are for, right? You stick by ’em, even when they drive you mad.  

...Unless they’re Snape. Then you’re allowed to lose patience.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Yeah, well—blimey, I *do* end up doing things last minute a lot, don’t I? Like that time I forgot about homework until Hermione was already halfway through hers, or when I only remembered Quidditch practice after Harry was already suited up. But, y’know, it usually works out—mostly. Sometimes you’ve just gotta wing it, even if it means dodging a few hexes or eating slugs along the way.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a heavy question. I dunno if I’d say *fascinated*, exactly—more like... it’s something I’ve had to reckon with, whether I wanted to or not. Losing people—Fred, Sirius, Dobby—it’s not something you just shrug off. But I’ve seen ghosts at Hogwarts, haven’t I? Nearly-Headless Nick, the Bloody Baron... makes you wonder, doesn’t it? Maybe there’s *something* after, but... I’d rather focus on the people still here. That’s what matters.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: Blimey, yeah, I s’pose I do. Never really liked bein’ alone—gets a bit… well, lonely, doesn’t it? Grew up in a house packed with family, and then at Hogwarts, there was always Harry and Hermione or the rest of the lot. Even when we argued—Merlin knows we had our rows—I’d still rather be with ‘em than stuck with my own thoughts. Not that I’m great at talking about feelings or anythin’, but… it’s better when you’ve got people around, innit? Makes the tough bits a bit easier.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: Oh, blimey—yeah, I reckon I do a bit. All that theoretical stuff gets a bit... well, boring, doesn’t it? I mean, I’d much rather be *doing* something, like playing Quidditch or working on a plan with Harry and Hermione. Theory’s fine when it’s useful, but if it’s just going on and on without any point, I start to zone out. Give me a real problem to solve any day—something with action, or at least a bit of danger. That’s when I really shine.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a tough one. I mean, I reckon it’s not always easy—like when Hermione first started going on about house-elves or when Hagrid was getting grief for being half-giant. But... you learn, don’t you? When you care about someone, you try to understand, even if it’s messy. Like with Harry—he’s been through stuff I can’t even imagine, but I’d still fight for him. And Merlin knows I’ve put my foot in it enough times to figure out that listening matters more than pretending you get it straight off.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: Blimey, no—I don’t usually put things off if I can help it. Learned that the hard way, honestly. Like when I hesitated to tell Hermione how I felt or when I nearly lost Harry as a mate because I was too busy sulking. But when it comes down to it—facing a chessboard full of deadly pieces or charging into a battle—I’d rather just get on with it. Overthinking’s more Hermione’s thing. Me? I’d rather jump in and figure it out as I go. Sometimes you just gotta act, even if it’s a bit mad.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: Blimey, second-guess my choices? Yeah, all the time. But—look, sometimes you’ve just got to go with your gut, right? Like when I followed Harry into the Department of Mysteries or when I came back during the Horcrux hunt. Yeah, I messed up a few times—who doesn’t?—but in the end, you stick by your mates, and that’s what matters. Even when it’s scary or you feel like a right idiot, you just... keep going. ‘S’not about never doubting—it’s about doing it anyway.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! After a rough week, nothing beats a good, loud party with friends—maybe even a bit of Butterbeer or a round of Exploding Snap. Though, honestly, I’d take just sitting by the fire in the common room with Harry and Hermione, laughing about something daft. As long as I’m with people who actually *get* me, y’know? ’Course, I could do without any more Acid Pops or pranks from the twins... blimey, that stung. But yeah, a bit of fun? Always helps.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: Oh, blimey... art museums? Er, not really my thing, to be honest. I mean, I reckon staring at old paintings is a bit dull compared to, say, a good game of Quidditch or a proper adventure with Harry and Hermione. Though, I did see some pretty mental stuff in the wizarding world—like those moving portraits at Hogwarts. Now *that’s* art worth looking at! But Muggle museums? Nah, I’d rather be eating a decent meal or having a laugh with my mates.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: Blimey, yeah, I reckon I do sometimes. I mean, I’ve messed up plenty—like when I got all jealous of Harry or didn’t realize how Hermione felt. But I try, you know? It’s just... feelings are bloody complicated. Sometimes I don’t get it right away, but when it matters, I’ll always stand by my friends. Even if it takes me a minute to catch on.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: Blimey, to-do lists? Nah, I’m not much for that sort of thing. I mean, Hermione’s always got one longer than a dragon’s tail, scribbling away like mad. But me? I reckon things just sort of... happen. Like, d’you plan on getting dragged into a life-or-death tournament or hunting Horcruxes? Course not! You just wing it and hope for the best. Though, er, maybe a list wouldn’t hurt when it comes to homework. Merlin knows I’ve lost track of how many times I’ve forgotten an essay.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: Blimey, ‘course I feel insecure. Loads of times, honestly. Like when Harry got all the attention or when I mucked up Quidditch so badly everyone sang that ruddy song about me. Or when Hermione and Harry were off being brilliant and I felt like I was just... there. But, y’know, you learn to push through it. Got my moments—like standing up to that git Malfoy or helping destroy a Horcrux—that prove I’m not completely useless. Just takes a bit to remember sometimes.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: Blimey, phone calls? Nah, I don’t mind ‘em, but I’d rather just pop ‘round to see someone face-to-face. ‘Course, with all the madness we’ve been through—Snape, Horcruxes, dodging Snatchers—you learn to appreciate a quick chat without Death Eaters eavesdropping. Though I reckon Hermione’d say I’m rubbish at leaving messages. Always forget the important bits.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: Erm... well, I reckon I don’t always *try* to understand different views, not at first, anyway. I mean, blimey, half the time I’m too busy arguing or being thick about things—like with Hermione and her bloody SPEW badges. But... I dunno, after a while, if it’s someone I care about, I usually come ‘round. Like with Harry and the whole Triwizard thing—I was a right git, but I got there in the end. Sometimes it just takes a bit of a knock to the head to see things proper.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Honestly, I reckon it’s a bit of both. I mean, I’m always up for a laugh or a game of chess, so yeah, I’ll drag Harry and Hermione into things when I’ve got an idea—like that time I nicked the flying car to rescue Harry from the Dursleys. Blimey, that went sideways quick. But sometimes, especially when I’m feeling a bit rubbish about myself, I’ll hang back and let them take the lead. Doesn’t mean I don’t care, though. Just... you know, figuring things out. But when it really matters, I’ll always be there. That’s what friends do, innit?

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: Blimey, when plans go sideways—which, honestly, happens a lot—I reckon my first instinct is to panic a bit. But then I remember who’s counting on me, yeah? Like when Harry and I missed the train and ended up flying that ruddy car into the Whomping Willow. Absolute disaster, but we didn’t just sit around moping—we sorted it, didn’t we? Even if it nearly killed us. Same with the Horcruxes. I walked out once—stupidest thing I ever did—but I came back. Because when it matters, you don’t just give up. You keep going, even if you’re scared spitless. That’s what friends do. That’s what *family* does.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response:
*shifts uncomfortably, scratches the back of his head* 

Yeah, course I am. Blimey, some of those things—like the slug-vomiting incident or walking out on Harry and Hermione during the Horcrux hunt—still make me cringe when I think about ‘em. But… *sighs* I reckon mistakes are part of it, aren’t they? Learned a lot from being a git. Still, wouldn’t change much—well, maybe the broken wand bit—because all that rubbish led me right back where I belonged in the end. With them. 

*grins weakly* Besides, if I hadn’t messed up, I’d never have known Harry always carries a bezoar. Mental, that.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: "Blimey, that’s a bit heavy, isn’t it? I mean, I reckon life’s about sticking with your mates and doing what’s right, even when it’s bloody terrifying. Dunno if there’s some grand meaning, but fighting alongside Harry and Hermione, saving people—that’s what matters to me. Oh, and not starving. Food’s pretty important too."

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a tough one. I dunno, sometimes I reckon my emotions do get the better of me—like when I stormed off in a huff over the Triwizard Tournament or when I couldn’t even talk to Fleur without making a complete prat of myself. But other times, like when Harry or Hermione needed me, I like to think I kept my head on straight. Well, mostly. It’s just... when it comes to the people I care about, I can’t help feeling things a bit loudly, y’know? Even if it lands me in trouble.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a tough one. Look, I’m not exactly the bloke who plans out every word—sometimes I just say things without thinking, and yeah, I’ve messed up because of it. But if someone’s really in the wrong? I’ll call it out, especially if they’re hurting people I care about. Saw enough of that with Malfoy and his lot. That said, I’m not about to kick someone when they’re down, even if they deserve it. Learned that the hard way after a few rows with Harry and Hermione. Sometimes... it’s better to just shut your gob and sort it out later.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: Oh, blimey—yeah, I s’pose I’m more of a “burst of energy” sort of bloke. I mean, look, I’ve had my moments where I’ve tried to be all organized—like when I was juggling prefect duties and D.A. meetings—but usually, it’s more like… well, things just *happen*, and I react. Like that time with the chessboard or when I had to distract Umbridge. Not exactly planned, but it worked, didn’t it? Though, uh, sometimes it backfires—like with that bloody wand in second year. But hey, at least I’m good in a pinch!

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: Blimey, yeah, I’ve thought about that loads. Used to reckon it was only a matter of time before people realized I wasn’t as great as they thought—like when I messed up in Quidditch or let jealousy get the better of me. But, y’know, over time I learned it’s not about living up to some impossible standard. My mates—Harry, Hermione, the lot of ‘em—they’ve stuck by me even when I was being a right git. Turns out, real friends don’t just vanish when you’re not perfect. They’re there for the good *and* the rubbish bits. Still, sometimes that voice in my head nags at me… but I try to ignore it. Mostly works.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: Blimey, no way! I'd go spare working alone all the time. What's the point of a job if you can't have a laugh with your mates while you're doing it? I mean, look, I've had my moments where I've needed to be on my own, but—let's be honest—I'm rubbish at it. Always end up missing Harry and Hermione, or getting into some stupid row because I'm overthinking things. Nah, give me a team any day. Even if it’s just George driving me mental at the joke shop—at least there’s someone to chuck a Dungbomb at when things get dull.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: Blimey, abstract philosophy? Sounds a bit like Hermione’s idea of a good time. I mean, I reckon it’s not *completely* useless—sometimes you’ve got to think about the big stuff, like why Dumbledore left Harry that stupid Snitch or why Fred and George’s pranks always work better than mine. But honestly, I’d rather be doing something proper, like chess or Quidditch. Or eating. Thinking too much gives me a headache.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: Oh, blimey, that’s a tough one. I mean, I grew up in the Burrow with all my brothers and Ginny—never a quiet moment there, was there? But honestly, it’s the noisy, mad places that feel like home. Like the Gryffindor common room or the Three Broomsticks when it’s packed. Though, don’t get me wrong, sometimes after a long day, it’s nice to just sit by the fire with Harry and Hermione, not saying much. But give me a crowd, a bit of chaos, and a game of chess or Quidditch—that’s when I feel most alive.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: Blimey, I reckon I can usually tell when someone’s upset or angry—like when Malfoy’s being a git, it’s written all over his face. But sometimes I get it all wrong, like when I thought Harry was loving all that Triwizard Tournament fame and he was actually miserable. Emotions are tricky, but if it’s someone I care about, I try my best to figure it out—even if it takes a bit of a row first.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Blimey, yeah, I reckon I do—more than I’d like to admit. Between dodging curses, worrying about my family, and trying not to muck things up with Hermione... it’s a lot. Sometimes it feels like the whole world’s on my shoulders, y’know? But—uh—I’ve got my mates, and that helps. Even when everything’s going sideways, sticking together makes it bearable.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: Blimey, methodical? Not exactly my strong suit, to be honest. I mean, I try, but things usually go a bit sideways—like that time with the Polyjuice Potion or when I splinched myself apparating. I reckon I’m more of a ‘jump in and figure it out as I go’ sort of bloke. But when it really matters—like standing by my mates or facing down a nest of giant spiders—I’ll see it through, even if I’m bricking it. Just don’t ask me to follow Hermione’s revision schedules. That’s a lost cause.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: Blimey, controversial stuff? I dunno—reckon I’ve had enough of that to last a lifetime. Between dark wizards, cursed objects, and my own brothers pranking me half to death, I’ve learned some things are controversial for a good reason. But if it’s about standing up for what’s right or protecting my friends? Yeah, I’ll dive in headfirst, no question. Just… maybe not another Acid Pop. That was a nightmare.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: Blimey, that’s a tough one. I reckon I would, yeah. I mean, look, I’ve been there—feeling like I’m not good enough or someone else deserves it more. But that’s rubbish, honestly. If it’s something I really care about, I’d fight for it. But if it’s clear someone else needs it more? Like, really needs it? Yeah, I’d step aside. Did it with the chessboard in first year, didn’t I? Sometimes you just know when it’s the right thing to do. Even if it stings a bit.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Oh, blimey, deadlines... yeah, I’ve had my fair share of struggles with those. Remember fifth year with O.W.L.s and Dumbledore’s Army? Bloody nightmare trying to balance it all—Hermione was mental with her schedules, and I was just trying to keep up. And don’t even get me started on that time I splinched myself apparating back to Harry and Hermione during the Horcrux hunt. But you know what? When it really matters, I get it done. Might not always be pretty, but I’ll fight through whatever it takes for my friends.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: Blimey, confident? Well... I dunno if I’d say *confident* exactly. But I’ve been through enough scrapes to know things usually work out in the end—even if it’s a bit dodgy getting there. Like, remember when we nicked that dragon out of Gringotts? Or when Harry faced You-Know-Who with a broken wand? Bloody mental, all of it. But we made it. And, er... I reckon if we can handle *that*, we can handle most things. Plus, I’ve got Hermione now. She’s brilliant at figuring stuff out when I’m busy panicking. So... yeah. Maybe not confident, but hopeful. And that’s... that’s something, innit?
